div.class: custom_104645 img-responsive no-border col-md-12 wow animated wow animated zoomIn

p.b: Washakie #1 has been working hard to develop plans for continuing student learning after spring break. Here are some key details for families:

li.b: The district is moving forward with a virtual learning model after spring break.
Students will not be on site until further notice.
We will continue with virtual learning until students are allowed to return to school.

p.b: This model presents challenges, yet district staff are committed to working with students and their families to ensure high levels of learning.
Please click to review the following links. Updates will be posted frequently as new information comes to the district.

b.u: School Closure – Frequently Asked Questions – FAQs
Free Learning Resources for Parents and Students
Students: Wireless Options for Students Who Do Not Currently Have Access to Internet at Home
Wyoming Department of Education – Adapted Learning Resources

div.button:
Hydrologic Outlook
Click for more Information

div.p: ...Melting Snow to Raise Foothill Water Levels This Week... High temperatures Wednesday and Thursday are expected to be 10 to 20 degrees above normal across almost all of western and central Wyoming. This will lead to daytime temperatures in the 50s and possibly the lower 60s for the mountains. Windy conditions and nighttime cloud cover may allow for snow to continue melting through the overnight hours. The result will be a period of active snowmelt with water levels expected to rise on foothill creeks, streams, and rivers. Flooding is not expected at this time as the waterways should have capacity to handle increased water flow. However, if you are planning recreation along these foothill waterways you should prepare for changing conditions and use extra caution. Rising water levels are expected to be most pronounced Wednesday through Friday.
